There are a lot of technical hurdles to implementing a radio function.

In order to do so, you need a server where music would be hosted for users to search from. You could use Amazon for this option.
I also learned you could stream using Spotify and Soundcloud provided SDK and API\'s.

You also need to request proper permissions for the device to use the internet.

Adding a store requires more activities, and billing functionality. As I mentioned in the about page I will be looking into two different ways of doing this. The Android Pay API and Android In-App Billing SDK.

Another difficulty of the store will be creating a place the user can shop for music.
The settings page would include options to manage subscriptions, payment methods etc.

Author: Caleb Imler

MusicPlayer is a project for Udacity/Google\'s Android Developer Nanodegree program.

Things not yet included in the app: Audio playback functionality, radio functionality, payment processing, importing music etc.

In order to add media player functionality, I will be researching the MediaPlayer API, which can be used for stored music, and streaming.

For processing payment I will be looking into the Android Pay API or the Android In-App Billing SDK.

The library, Radio and Settings pages are incomplete.

In the Library, I plan to make each TextView link to a page that organises the user\'s music appropriately. From the artists page, if you select an artist, it will bring up all of their albums, if you have multiple to choose from. If you select the songs TextView, it will take the user to a page of all songs, listed alphabetically by song title. I will follow that pattern for the other views.

The Radio Activity, if I choose to keep it and implement the functionality, would have a search function for finding music from an external database, or host my own server, in which case I would have to get licensing to share my music. Similar to other apps of this type, it would allow you to create stations based on an artist/song/genre/etc.

Within the Store Activity, users would be able to search for music. The home screen would display currently trending and new music. I may also consider learning to integrate location data and display music that is popular in the user\'s area.

Finally, under the settings menu, I would include settings for account subscriptions, payment methods, storage options etc.

I hope that my intentions with the app are clear, and navigating it is simple. I feel like I could easily get carried away with this project, trying to make a fully functional app. It has been a learning process figuring out how to incorporate a toolbar and menu as well.
